title: Stepper Motor Mount to Aluminum Extrusion

description.text: I originally fabricated a metal bracket for my printer but it transferred too much motor noise to the printer's frame. I designed this one to help with that and it did at least with the higher frequencies. Works great for keeping a low profile when used for the Y-Axis but I suppose could be used in other ways.

Printer:

Model 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I recommend printing with support under the motor mount face. That way when you mount the motor it will hide most of the surface that was supported.

Hardware Required

Designed with the following socket or button head cap screws:
M3 x 20mm screws - 4 EA
M5 x 8mm screws and your nuts of choice - up to 5 EA
Depending on your mounting requirements you may only need to use one or four of the M5 screws

author: cablestud

description.text:
(New improved version! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:204657) A fun flat print you can glue a magnet on and stick on a fridge, preferably near a bunch of other magnets! Made with Solidworks. Had several designs in mind, went with this one.
Suggestions for improvements are welcome. (Yes, the red in the picture is just wishful thinking... Maybe I can spray paint just that face after printing, somehow...) (The fridge photo shows the 2D version I made a few of, oh so many years ago.) If you print it and love it, please do upload a Make and consider tipping! :)
Also please check my profile for my Etsy, Pinshape etc...
I suggest no higher than 0.25mm layer height, and maybe a silver filament... or maybe white so you can color it easily afterwards.

description.text:
jthriller created some pretty dang good clamps to hold onto skateboard ball bearings. His original design required you to buy an 8mm diameter dowel for the bearings. This just adds a printable 10cm rod with diameter of 8mm.

Added a half dowel, in case you're having trouble printing the dowel as a whole. Rotate it to rest on the flat face and then print two. It might not roll work as well if you print as halves.

description.text:
Found this awesome file here http://www.blendswap.com/blends/view/86558
I spent the last week stripping the shells back. If you would like the suit you can grab all the files already devided up over at my shop on Etzy and create your own fully wearable suit ; ) Merry Xmas Cheers Jace.

Grab it from me at Etsy and take the time to slice it up ready to print your self.
https://www.etsy.com/nz/listing/500795627/rogue-1-death-trooepr-armour?ref=shop_home_active_1

When I first found it, it was free. Their obvioulsy charging for it now sorry.
you know what site? and where to get it.
Ahhh, the links been in the description the whole time?
you know what you should do. you should create the same file but in a form that can be used on 3D max. but this is really is incredible
I think it was originally a .FBX file.
this is incredible.
Thanks : ) But i can take all the credit for it as it was originally a free download off the internet. All I've done is strip it down into components  hopefully to a printable state. Cheers Jace

title: Quantum Game and Board/Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays This is my take on a printable version of the abstract strategy game Quantum with a printable case that doubles as a game board. Because the pieces are slightly different I'll eventually have to type out some new rules for it, but for now the link below should be any intelegent maker started. For rules and information see: http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/5221/quantum This part was made with Tinkercad (with some minor clean up in Blender afterwards). Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/7pUCHxgbgBO Thanks to MakesALot for showing this game to me. EDIT: Quick change that adds lettering to the box.

If you are printing this on a TOM you will need to scale everthing by 0.75 to make it fit.
  • Print out 2 pieces plates, one for each color.
  • (Optionally) Print out the board and lid.
  • Place the tabs of the board into the slots lid to form the game board.
  • Put pieces in their designated start spots.
  • Play Quantum.
    • When you are done.
  • Remove the pieces from the board.
  • Flip the board over.
  • Put all pices in the board.
  • Put the lid on being sure to slot the tabs in the appropiate place.

author: cymon

title: 2.5" hard drive bracket for Hammond 1455R / 1455T aluminum cases

description.text:
This bracket is designed to hold 2.5" hard drives within a 165mm wide, Hammond 1455R or 1455T series extruded aluminum enclosure. Drives are screwed to the brackets, and the edges of the brackets rest in the card slots along the edge of the enclosure.

Two brackets can support one drive (parallel to the brackets, perpendicular to the enclosure) or two drives (perpendicular to the brackets, parallel to the enclosure). 15mm tall drives can be stacked 1-high in a 1455R case, or 2-high in a 1455T series case.

Use M3x0.5 thread, 4-6mm length pan head screws to attach drives to bracket. The recesses for the screw heads are 7mm in diameter; screws with a head diameter of 6mm or less is recommended.

comments.text: Now that I've finally got this 3D printed (hah) I made a couple small dimensional changes to the bracket so it fits the case a bit better.

title: MendelMax Filament Guides & Guide Wheel & spool holder

description.text:
Set of filament guides for a MendelMax printer. I have had all sorts of problems with filament tangling during printing, so I created these guides to eliminate any possible issues. It includes two options for the upper guide- one fixed curved guide, and one rotating wheel.   
All guides are designed for 3mm filament. The rotating guide wheel would work for 1.75mm filament as well.   
The side-mount spool holder should work with most filament spools.  
1/1/2014 Update: Added dual wheel upper guide and dual bearing lower guide for even lower friction filament feeding- hopefully equaling better part print quality

The rotating upper filament guide wheel needs the following "vitamins" to build:
-2x M8 x 30mm SHCS
-2x M8 nut
-~4x M8 washers
-4x 608 bearings You'll need to print 2x of the wheels. I'd recommend that you place 3-4 washers between the two bearings in each of the wheels, so when you tighten the M8 screw it doesn't apply a side-load to the bearings and bind them up. The lower filament guide requires 2x 608 bearings, and 3x M8x30mm SHCS. The holes are sized to tap the holes and not use a nut on the back. All other parts are self-explanatory.

author: BobYoung

description.text:
When the chrome layer starts to peel off, this is the thing you want to print ;)
Knob is designed for an M6 bolt&nut.
Print with the hole down on the bed and pause just before the hexagon cut out changes back to a circle. Check this in your slicer and note the height or the layer number.
If you use a bolt, you will need to print the knob at a height of bolt length -15mm or -10mm depending on the STL you use. Add a couple of mm for safety.
I use Simplify 3D to slice and one can put an object at some height above the bed and then generate support. Modify support as needed and don't forget to remove all support under the hole where the bolt has to be inserted!
I included 2 versions (see cross sections above) for different bolt lengths. Holes are 25mm deep. Bolt starts in the 15-5-5 version at 15mm, in the 10-5-10 version at 10mm.

You could also use 2 versions with a nut and use a piece of (stainless) threaded rod

Printer:

Folgertech FT5

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

You don't want to have support in the hole! check that before printing!
Support is only needed if you print a knob at height when using a bolt. Within S3D (our your slicer) remove all support under the hole with the manual support tool.
Check also INSIDE the bolt in your slicer preview.
just a standard 1.75mm strand. Should work with most printers.

To keep track of the initiative order in games like Dungeons and Dragons.

You may want to create custom clamps for each of the player characters. If so, see the link to Tinkercad.

This project consists of five parts:
Initiative Pole: This is the upright thing to place the clamps on.
Initiative Clamp: Basic blank clamp.
Initiative Clamp x8: Eight blank clamps.
Initiative Clamp 5 10 15 20 25 "Roll clamps": These indicate the initiative roll and would be placed on one side of the pole. Move up or down depending on how well spaced the character clamps are.
Initiative Clamps numbered 1-8 "Enemy clamps": Use these to indicate enemies (numbered to easier keep track of which i which).

Printer:

Sculpto

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal

If you want to make the indentations on the clamps more readable trace them with a 'paint marker' or fill the indentation with acrylic paint and let it dry before flipping it over and doing the other side.

My initial ide was to have a 'pole' with numbers on one side and moveable 'character' camps om the other. The problem with having the numbers directly on the pole was however that it had to be pretty tall to allow having two characters in the same initiative.
Even if only making the numbers in the central part of the spectrum tall enough to allow space for two (10-20) the pole was going to be tall.
Try as I might I did not find a good way to make the three pieces of the pole fit together without becoming a wobble-mess.

After having tried with a somewhat wobbly pole for a couple of games I discovered that the exact number in the order was not as important as the order.

Therefore this version only have one part on the pole and there are no numbers on it. There are 'initiative roll clamps' with the values 5, 10, 15, 20 and 25 on them and at the start of the initiative roll they are spaced on one side of the pole.
As the character clamps are added to the opposite side of the roll-clamps, these may be moved up or down.
Once all characters have been placed into the order we usually move all the character clamps to the top.

Some of the early versions where not only comprised of a lot of pieces but were also bulky and difficult to keep together.

Items also available on tinkercad:

Roll Clamps: https://tinkercad.com/things/cqjI45t97xP
1-8 Clamps: https://tinkercad.com/things/hj8SW9p9TjB
Blank Clamp: https://tinkercad.com/things/7yC6K0r5SxB (has 'hole' letters that you can use to customise the clamp with player names)
Blank Clamp x8: https://tinkercad.com/things/4n5DxyAcgRM

description.text:
Very Big Z braces for modifiaed Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, Maker Select, and Malyan M150 i3 3D printers.
Mod only for advanced user.
I do not advise on the creation of this mod.

comments.text: I have done a similar mod extending the z-axis with 600mm rods, and have also extended the y-axis to 300mm. Extending the z height above 350mm means you will need to extend the wires for the x motor. A total z height of about 450mm is possible with 600mm threaded rods. Extending any axis leads to wire management issues especially the y. I have found no need as yet to extend the z brace any higher than standard although I am using far more substantial material for my z axis than shown here. I have designed my own extensions for the y which incorporate Azza's z brace. I now have a total build volume of 200x300x450mm, 3.75x bigger than standard and the print quality is still fantastic. All one really needs to extend the z is accurate measuring equipment and access to a pillar drill. Extending the y however is quite simple. Extending both axis cost me £96

title: Prusa i3 Steel upgrade X-carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the x-carriage designed for my upgrade set to use 10mm steel bars and bushes for my Prusa i3 Steel derivative.

Comprised of two parts held together by M3 cap screws, it is designed for 4 by 20 x 10 mm Oilite bushes.

The X-belt is simply pushed into the gripper (I use a small quantity of soapy water to help insert it).

I have added holes to allow the bushes to be oiled. The rear component has two small holes on top and two at the rear for this purpose and I just inject a few drops of oil into these using a syringe. To hold the oil, on mine I added small felt pads wrapped around the 10mm rod into the central groove.

The 3mm holes on the underside of the rear part are for optional 3mm rare earth magnets that can be used to hold things like layer fan ducts etc.

description.text: Quick Santa Hat I whipped up in Sketchup.  Was testing out my dual extrude functionality on my Rep 1 and thought it would make a good season-appropriate thing.

Center everything. The lower part of the hat sits flush with the build plate. The cone sits 6.35mm above the lower part (or .25"). The puff ball sits ~42.45mm (~1.67") above the cone. The ball should overlap with the cone a bit, it is ok and still prints but I was afraid that the ball would snap off so I overlapped things a bit. The puff ball is taken from Smooth Sphere by 3dPrintNewsNow. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:115644 You have to scale it to 33% (it is originally 48mm in diameter)

title: Customizable award base with mount hole

description.text:
I needed a custom award base that has a mounting hole for a statue (or anything you want to put onto the base). The holeEnabled customizer parameter allows you to print the base with or without the hole, and you can set its size with the holeWidth, holeLength and holeDepth parameters.

Thanks for TheNewHobbyist for the Customizable Movie Award Base that was the source of this model, however I significantly refactored and commented the source code, and also changed some metrics.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

With the printItem customizer parameter you can define what part of the model you want to print:

  • Set it to Both to print the base and the label in one object.
  • Set it to Base only to print the base only without the label. I recommend using black PLA.
  • Set it to Label only to print the label only, for example for painting. I printed it using the same black PLA, and then painted it to gold. You can probably use gold PLA as well.

It took about 2 hours to print the base only, and another 15 minutes to print the label. The label is 3 mm thick, I recommend printing it as a solid object.

By setting the prinItem parameter to Label only, you can print the label as a separate object, paint it and then glue it to the base. This way you can apply different print settings for the label, for example you can print it with 0.1 mm resolution. Before painting you probably want to sand it slightly.

description.text:
This is a simple model of a Swiss lever flying tourbillon as found in many high-end watches. A tourbillon is a feature designed by Breguet as a method to counter gravitational errors on the balance spring and improve watch accuracy. This tourbillon, however, was designed by me as a method to demonstrate horological nerdom to others.

vocabulary lesson:
tourbillon - a mechanism to counter the effects of gravity by rotating the escapement and balance wheel so all errors average out.
"flying" - cantilevered off of only one pivot. "Flying" sounds more dramatic and sells more watches than "cantilevered."
swiss lever - the most ubiquitous mechanical watch escapement in the world originally invented by Thomas Mudge. Its simplicity and ability to self start account for its popularity despite less than ideal efficiency and sliding friction from the pallets.

Originally I wanted it to be powered by my ID tags, but it requires more weight (or a bigger spocket). So now it runs off of six quarters taped to the end of my ID tag chain (standard #3 ball chain). It keeps fairly accurate time at 1 RPM, but I left holes in the balance wheel into which one can thread grub screws to adjust the speed.

See it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wy9oI43SeyU&feature=youtu.be

I designed it yesterday evening and printed it this morning, so I may not have caught all errors. It seems to work quite well, but please shoot me a comment should anyone discover any issues while attempting to make one.

I attempted to keep the part count (printed and hardware) as low as possible. In addition to the printed pieces (less than four hours of print time and 32g plastic). This design requires the following (Barbarians that do not stock shafts and ball bearings should consult the update below for an alternative):

3 x 20mm long 2mm shafts
1 x 30mm long 3mm shaft
2 x 6x2.5x3 RC helicopter bearings

Here are links for the non-printed components I used. Anything comparable will do.
bearings: https://www.amazon.com/Sixteen-MR63-3x6x2mm-Precision-Bearings/dp/B01M0VV96I/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1483062996&sr=8-2&keywords=3mm+id+ball+bearing
3mm rods: https://www.amazon.com/10Pcs-Stainless-Steel-Cylinder-Linear/dp/B00JR56KI0/ref=sr_1_1?rps=1&ie=UTF8&qid=1483063060&sr=8-1&keywords=3mm+shaft&refinements=p_85%3A2470955011
2mm rods: https://www.amazon.com/20Pcs-Stainless-Steel-Round-150mmx2mm/dp/B00KHUR5AQ/ref=sr_1_1?rps=1&ie=UTF8&qid=1483063100&sr=8-1&keywords=2mm+shaft&refinements=p_85%3A2470955011
inspiration: https://www.bulleit.com/whiskeys/bulleit-rye/

UPDATE 04FEB17: Due to several requests for designs that do not require metal shafts and ball bearings (and also due to the fact that my Dremel is half way across the ocean), I added new versions of parts designed for 1.75 filament shafts. Basically, any file with a "-2" in its name has been re-dimensioned for the thinner, floppier shafts.

To use, straighten spare lengths of filament and thread them through the holes of rotating parts so that about 4mm is sticking out of each end. Sand the ends of the filament lengths so that they are rounded. This version may no longer be called a flying tourbillon on account of the bridge, but the mechanism is identical. It also prints a few minutes faster.

This new version is just as reliable as the previous one although operation is a little rougher. I doubt many of my other designs will be as forgiving of the filament shaft conversion, but who knows? Anyway, I would be interested in hearing about others' experiences with this update and whether it's something worth pursuing in future designs even after I am reunited with my Dremel.

print_settings.Notes:: Motorside and Pullyside with bottom(1/4 screw holes) on bed

description.text:
With these parts you can upgrade a normal ball bearing Cameraslider to a motorized one.
Everything is designed for this slider from Amazon that i own.
If you tweak the carriage mount a little bit, you should be able to use one of these Sliders that are similar to mine:
You only need to Print the files and add the following parts (i assume that you already have things like resistors, wire, solder, soldering iron e.g.):

  • Nema 17 Motor
  • A4988 Stepper Driver
  • Arduino Nano
  • gt2 pully
  • gt2 belt
  • 2x Leds
  • potentiometer
  • tactile switch
  • 4x 1/4 inch Screws
  • m4 screw ***
  • 2x m3 Screw
  • m3 nut

*** only if you have the exact same Slider as me

The Software that i programmed is available at my Website.

Printer:

Zonestar D810

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

ONE OF THE SIDES MUST BE MIRRORED

The parts should be oriented as listed below:

  • Motorside and Pullyside with bottom(1/4 screw holes) on bed
  • Pully and endstop with outside (biggest diameter) on bed
  • Carriagemount with top on bed
  • Carriage beltholder with side on bed
  • Motorcover with wider side (top) on bed

1. Install Stepper in motorside
  2. Wire electronics like the wiring diagramm (Fritzing file)
  3. install Electronics in motorside and motorCover
  4. install pully at the pullyside
  5. install both sides on the slider
  6. install the belt holder to the carriage
  7. install Pully to Stepper and connect the gt2 Belt
Download Fritzing file, to view connections in detail See it in Action :) [GERMAN audio]

description.text:
Second iteration of the Quadra-Pigeon.  
Longer, hollow arms.  
Rubber mounted motors.  
Rubber mounted control board.  
Electronics protected by a cover.  
All the old camera mount stuff is scraped away.  
Lots and lots of small changes.  
I finally gave up on using Sketch up. I was spending the lion's share of my time trying to overcome weird issues and not moving forward on the model at all. This was a good project to get better acquainted with Solidowokrs, so that's what happened. This machine is all modeled in Solidworks.  
I have the airframe pretty much the way I want it. Next is to design a gimbaled camera mount.

Arms were printed @ 25% fill. You can -just- print them without supports. Top & bottom are 20% fill, no supports. There are four mounting holes on the top plate that need to be tapped 1/4-20 to accept the mounting bolts for the top cover"Igloo". The holes are already the correct size so its a snap to do. Solidworks doesn't support modeling of threads. :( Igloo top cover is 10% fill. If you place it upside down you don't need supports. Same set of hardware as the original Quadra-Pigeon.
See : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:186402
For the list of hardware that fits this. In addition your going to need 24 rubber grommets. I think they are 1/8" inside Dia, 1/4" outside Dia. 1/16" panel thickness. I found 'em at the local hardware store. Have tested flying this one. Flies great, large and scary!

comments.text: So I'm seeing something like 40 odd downloads. Is -anyone- printing this or to people just collect them?

author: alejandro_el73

description.text:
This is a battery pack for those cheap drills that were produced around 2003 - 2015. Einhell, Defort, Ferm, Challenge, Amtech, ProUser, Speedway, Workzone, Power-G, Boston, Draper, XU1, Trades Pro and Top Craft (maybe Mastercraft) made (or relabeled) them. Most of those drills aren't too bad, but the batteries suck. All of my standard 18V batteries (I have 4 of these machines with 6 battery packs) are on their last breath, so I decided to upgrade them to Li-Ion using 18650 cells.

The files contain the original Sketchup file and the STL for printing. I usually draw stuff that's more functional than beautiful, so go wild on the design if you want to. :)

I got about 8 hours print time at a very strong pace. With less agressive settings I imagine 10 - 12 hours would do the trick.

Grtz Dustin

Printer:

FixrBot 1.0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

300µm

Infill:

85%

Battery requirements

You can use 4 or 8 18650 cells with up to 5 Ah at 14,8V. If you have a drill with a simular battery but a smaller voltage pack, you could wire it differently. 7,4V with 10Ah! or 11,1 V with 5Ah. (only 6 cells in this case)

Stay away from the cheap china cells because they will give you a bad time. They are labeled 6,8Ah or more, but are not even 1Ah. That's fine, if you know what you are buying. Panasonic/LG/Sony is the way to go. Worn laptop batteries will do fine too and usually outperform brand new china cells.

Assembly

Put big washers (same size as the tubes if you can find them) inside the pipes for the battery and on the lid, insert M4 (16-20mm long) bolts (or whatever non-metric stuff you have to use) and tighten them with a M4 nut. Do this on the lid and the housing for the negative terminals. On the positive terminals leave out the big washer.

Find suitable springs and drop them inside the tubes on the negative sides of the cells. Finding good springs is a bit of a challenge.

Then make wires and put the top pack in series and the bottom pack in series. Make a bridge between the two 4S packs. Screw it down with another nut. Use good wiring. I use 2,5mm² hard copper wire. My drills can draw up to 15A of power. Screw the lid on the housing.

Measure your voltages. If you run into trouble, check each cell. A spring might have made bad contact. Also check your polarity on the part that goes inside the machine. Usually it's marked on the machine or your old battery pack

Run the positive and negative wire from the packs through the housing and up the part that goes inside the drill. Find metal plates that fit inside the contact. Solder them to your wires. I used hot glue to fix the plates in place

Fit inside your machine. Li-Ion upgrade complete !

Stuff you'll need.

4 or 8 18650 cells
Copper wire
8x big (18mm dia max) washer.
16x M4 bolt 16 or 20mm long (or whatever non-metric bolts that fit)
32x M4 nut
Soldering iron
Tin
Plates for contacts
Hot glue gun
Multimeter

Safety warnings

Li-Ion cells are dangerous. Improper use can cause violent explosions or fire. Soldering can cause burns.

WARNING : YOU CAN NOT CHARGE THIS PACK IN YOUR STANDARD CHARGER !!!

The standard charger is made for Ni-Ca batteries and therefor not suitable for charging this pack. It will melt, burn or even explode! You have been warned. :)

Charging

I have a bunch of these cells lying around. I just replace them and recharge them with a normal 18650 charger. You can also use a LiPo-pack charger, set it to 4S2P and leave the batteries in.

I might model a charger later on to hook up to my regulated power supply.

Thoughts

Well, in my search for replacement batteries i found so many brands who relabeled these machines... it would be interesting to find the original manufacturer, or where they copied this design from? Does anyone have a clue?

title: Charging Cable Guides for MacBook (Pro) - 15" and 12" (2016)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I was disappointed to find that the 2016 MacBook Pro's charging cable no longer had the two little clasps that would hold the cable when not in use. So, I made my own alternative.

This build has two main functions:
(1) Bundle the small USB-C wire when not in use.
(2) Keep the main charging unit supported and off the ground (in particular, carpet) when charging your laptop to permit better heat transfer.

I have iterated it a few times to get it to snap onto the charger without fracturing when made of PLA. I found that rotating it onto the charger is the best way to attach it.

I hope you enjoy, and don't forget to post photos of your makes.

title: Heavy Duty Geeetech gt2560 - jp-6445a case

description.text:
Ok I have made a Megalith reprap Monster of a style printer, print size is 52cm x 52cm x 52cm and i have issues with torque... the Nema 17 simply doesnt cut it. It skips to often carrying a lot of weight which includes silicone heater, a 5 mm thick aluminum bed and 5mm thick glass. So now I have upgraded the Y access to a nema 23 4a which handles it quite well with a new stepper driver Jp-6445a... I have replaced to power this beast.

Also for best results you may have to enlarge the print by 1 mm if the print isn't fitting well.

title: Catan terrain tiles, modified for cylindrical magnets

description.text:
UPDATE: Remixed for dual magnets per side, here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2093075

I had 3 mm x 1 mm cylindrical magnets sitting around. These did not fit into Dakanzla's bases particularly well (and it required many magnets). I've modified all the terrain tiles to have 3 mm slots in the sides of the bases to allow magnet-to-magnet contact, which makes the interaction stronger. The only catch with this is that you have to get the polarization right for the bases. Basically, just alternate polarization as you go around the base. Will add a video shortly to show how I do this and makes it very quick.

Note: The only tiles where you start with the polarization matters are the ports. 6 ports need to have consistent polarization with the "port face", and 3 ports need to have the "port face" have opposite polarization.

https://youtu.be/UI5G3S1SCW8

comments.text: Thanks. I don't really do anything special. I painted some miniatures back in the day and watched the "Hot Lead" video to get some ideas of how to do some things. Dry brushing really helps a lot to highlight and differentiate details, so if that is something you aren't doing, it can help a lot.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
A snowman made in ice :)

The picture shown also features:

  • the great Snowflake designed by jonmonaghan
  • another thing I designed and print for this year end, the Stared Christmas Tree

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.6 mm

Notes:

Print with clear PLA or PET.
Use a wide nozzle (mine was an E3D 0.8 mm mounted on a v6 hotend, modified i3) and enforce even wider extrusion (I used 1.2 mm).
The relatively big layer height helps transparency, hence providing the ice look, while the large extrusion width helps with some almost horizontal surfaces (e.g. shoulders area).
Use 0-3 base layers (as you wish) and "vase mode" for the rest. Obviously no infill, no support, no raft (given the layer height, you should not have any issues with bed alignment, however use an appropriate surface for your material.
Print slow to allow for cooling and/or use a cooling fan (PLA).
It may take 20-40 minutes depending on the speed settings.

The printer and the filament PET-G was kindly provided by FORMWERK.
The design was made in 123D Design and required a small correction in MeshMixer to allow for proper vase mode all the way up.

remixed_from.author: w3ace
remixed_from.title: Evergreen Tree Christmas Ornament on Card

description.text:
That's my "star version" of the excellent Evergreen Tree Christmas Ornament on Card by w3ace.

The picture shown also features:

  • the great Snowflake designed by jonmonaghan
  • another thing I designed and print for this year end, the Iceman

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

20%/100%

Notes:

Well, this cannot be delivered "on card".
Actually it prints in 3 distinct jobs:

  • the branches are printed in green; I found 20% honeycomb infill to provide the best look and rigidity;
  • the trunk is filled to 100%, you can make it brown, but I suggest to use green;
  • print the star the color and way you like.
    All the pieces are pretty thin, so it will take not so much. Obviously, you may print many at a time.
    I used 0.25 mm layer height and 0.5 mm extrusion width, with 3 perimeters

The printer and the filament PLA was kindly provided by FORMWERK.
Sketches done in Inkscape, then imported in 123D Design, and extruded.

comments.text: found
comments.author: Ricc_D

comments.text: Where is the Snowman? :)
comments.author: Ricc_D

comments.text: Super Job. Really nice variation. It is so rewarding to see people taking my design and expanding on it. Long live the Creative Commons and iterative - cooperative design.

I used Windows 10's 3D Builder.
Dice with texts, made with openscad (parametrizable)

Designed using openscad

It has been designed to be a parametrizable dice, changing size, texts and font.

It contains basic openscad functions (translate, rotate, difference, intersection, cube, sphere, text with custom fonts). The inner part of the dice is hollow to save printing material.

If you want to edit this dice, you'll have to set a TTF font and update the first lines in the .scad file.

Slight modification on Tech2C's wonderful Hypercube 3D printer's x carriage. This mod makes the left hand side belt clamp stronger by allowing the screws go from the back all the way to the front of x carriage. Also fill up the original nut holes which make it weaker (mine snap right over there when I tighten the belt). It was a pain to insert the nut into those tiny holes in the original design.

comments.text:
Thank you for this mod.I had the same problem, i drilled the screw holes right through the carriage,so i could fit a nut on the back.
Your solution is much neater,so i'll use that instead.I also printed a thicker bar to hold the belts down as i found that was bending with the force required to hold the belt(4mm thickness).
comments.author: clogs

comments.text: You are welcome. I assume you knew this already, but the upper belt and lower belt were wrap in different direction such that their teeth facing each other. That way, when you cable tie them, they "bite" into each other and won't slip. So its really the cable tie that hold them together. I learn this from my other 3D printer. Cheers.

title: i3 Flex Coupling - Multiple Screw Holes

description.text:
Updated: Now you can define an array of screw holes to have as many or as few as you want. Default is now to have 3 screw holes. I had a problem due to high room temp with the lubricant I put on the threaded rod over time getting in the coupling and making it slip.
Even tightening the screw would only last so long. I made this mod to have double screws to help grip the rod.

title: Camera bed mount - Logitech C910 on Wanhao Duplicator 6 or Monoprice Maker Ultimate

description.text:
Another niche item, but possibly useful to a small set of people. I found a bunch of Logitech C910 designs here, but none that were quite what I had in mind, so I drew up this one.

Mounts to the bed support of the Monoprice Maker Ultimate (which is just a rebadged Wanhao Duplicator 6) so the camera is fixed to the bed, making the time lapse videos better.

Two designs - the initial had a clip to hold it in place, but I wasn't as happy with that design. It was what I did first and it works, so including it. The second design has provision for M5 set screws. No threads are included as I have a tap and die set which gives better results.

The camera mount itself has one side opened for an M4 bolt to pass through, and the other size smaller so it can be threaded for whatever M4 bolt you have on hand. Might work without a tap and die.

Original SketchUp design included.

Demo timelapse video from OctoPrint with the camera mounted on the bed: https://youtu.be/usDedkFrbwk

Related: If you use OctoPrint, the autofocus on the C910 can be really annoying as the moving print head confuses it. To disable the autofocus and set it to what for me is the middle of the print bed:

  • sudo apt install uvcdynctrl
  • add the following lines to your /etc/rc.local before the exit 0 at the bottom:
    uvcdynctrl -s "Focus, Auto" 0
    uvcdynctrl -s 'Focus (absolute)' 122

Yes, I know /etc/rc.local is old school and sloppy, but it works.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed with supports, left some of them in place as I thought it looked cool.

comments.text: How can I mix it with a phone holder, so I can mount an Android phone as webcam?
comments.author: yufanyufan

comments.text: There's a bunch of mounts that I've seen for each phone I've owned. Find one of those, and you might be able to use something like meshmixer or any other number of tools to combine them in some way that might be useful. Who knows, there might even be a mount out there already, I haven't looked.
comments.author: yufanyufan

comments.text: Wow. This is exactly what I needed. Same printer and camera. Thanks so much, I can't wait to print this. I (or someone) might have to tweak it a bit to see if it can fit with the acrylic panels attached. For now it will work great.
comments.author: Nbachman

comments.text: Awesome, glad to hear it! Thought it would be a bit too unique with both that camera and printer, but glad to hear it'll work for you.
comments.author: Nbachman

comments.text: Looks like I have a C920 though, so close but very different. Already have a quick fix or possibly a remix in my brain. Deciding whether or not to do a new design or try to "fix" yours. It is a beautiful starting point though. thanks for that.
comments.author: cmh

comments.text: From what I'm seeing, the C920 has a much better original mount - you could do something simple that uses a 1/4-20" bolt that goes into the tripod mount on the bottom of the 920. The original mount on the C910 makes no sense at all, so I was happy to tear that off. I was really lucky that I'm a bit of a pack rat and had an M4 screw exactly the size I needed on hand.
comments.author: Nbachman

title: Lime Pestle : Pilon à citron vert pour caipirinha, mojito, puch, ti-puch...et cocktail avec du citron

description.text:
Voila un pilon pour écraser les citrons verts (couper le citron vert en 4 ou 8 suivant la taille) et utiliser le pilon dans le verre directement.
Le bas du pilon est fourni en 2 versions (conique et taille de guèpe)
Coller le manche et le pilon à la colle chaude
Imprimer avec au moins 30% de remplissage et 3 à 4 couches sur la coque (il y a besoin de force)

Here is a pestle to crush the green lemons (cut the lime in 4 or 8 depending of the size) and use the pestle in the glass directly.
The bottom of the pestle is supplied in 2 versions (conic and waist)
Glue the handle and the pestle to the hot glue
Print with at least 30% filling and 3 to 4 layers on the hull (need strength)

remixed_from.author: sirmakesalot
remixed_from.title: Lightsaber with internal components mega project!

title: Lightsaber with working Laser and internal components

description.text:
This is a remix with custom parts to 3D print a lightsaber that has a real laser fitted inside.

WARNING!!! This is not a toy. The laser it's made for is very dangerous and will permanently blind you if the beam enters an eye! Even with "star cap" that usually comes with it direct eye contact should be avoided. Please take all safety precautions that you would do with a laser. As the switch button is flimsy and safety lock is open, treat it as if it can spontaneously turn on at any time. Always keep a "star cap" on, except directly before a demonstration (such as shining a beam to the stars - take care to avoid any aircraft traffic). The cap splits and fuzzies the beam and some say makes it relatively safe. Still don't point it to people's faces. Generally be very responsible with it. It's for costume and display purposes only, do not do stunts with it, it can disintegrate. Sorry for the long warning, but please take it seriously and don't do anything stupid. If you decide to build it - do it on your own risk. You have been warned.

Laser type: search for "303 laser" on eBay or Ali. It should have a button on the side, a safety lock with key on the butt, come with star cap (or several), and it should be powered by a lithium 18650 type battery. Make sure to buy a couple of batteries and a charger. Cost with charger one battery can be as low as $10 USD. You can get red (dimmest), green (brightest) and blue (most powerful but dimmer than green). I suggest green as it is brightest of them all. Blue is twice as powerful for the same or less brightness, so I think there is no need to make it more dangerous than it is. 303 laser without cap will shine a visible beam at night over several kilometers. You can point the stars and constellations in the sky and illuminate a treeline over the lake etc. Again, be very careful, never use close to other people.

External parts are combined from different remixes (I printer the wrong body parts so had to glue them, but included correct ones that should be screwed on both sides). Internal parts are hollowed out and new ones are created to fit the laser. In my experience printing with Tevo Tarantula I had to file some plastic off and make all kinds of adjustments post-print to make everything fit correctly. Some parts are glued together with AC glue or superglue. So it will need some tweaking after you print it. I have made a small foam cushion wrapped with aluminum tape to serve as a spring to push laser up. Small spacers are there to be glued to internal cup for it to fit better if needed. They may not be needed with the parts provided, or can be scaled to provide the distance you will need to cover with your particular printer. Look at my photos, it should be clear what goes where.

There are two versions of an internal firing cap - one that has slot for the laser button to go in and serve as a retainer so the laser won't fall out. If you want the slot to go all the way you might want to cut the plastic between the slot and the button hole. I did. But the cap was too flimsy after that so I had to reinforce it. So I think it's better not to cut it, there should be enough room for the button to squeeze by. If you want not to have a slot at all - there is a part with just enlarge opening for the laser diameter, without additional slots. You can customize it.

Once assembled, measure where the laser button is, and if everything has worked out, you need to drill a hole exactly where the top button is supposed to go, use provided button model, tape button from inside so it won't fall down, try it, make sure it's working, then measure the button part that's sticking out and scale faux button parts to glue next to the functional button.

I have painted it with acrylic metallic paints using wet and dry brushing technique for aged metal look. Printed in black and red PLA.

author: glmoulton

description.text:
My wife says that I don't have Christmas spirit, so I decided to do Christmas how I wanted to do Christmas! I remixed it, and learned some things along the way. This Christmas tree allows you to insert three NeoPixel Ring 12 x 5050 (product ID 1643). There is also inserts for the inside of rings so you don't see through them.

The hole at the top is to allow you to use string to hang from somewhere.

The stands at the back are ok, but I've included the 123D file incase you want to make them better. I'm posting this on the 23rd so you can guess there's no time to fix and reprint!

I used an Arduino Uno that I had going spare to drive the LEDs. The code is included, I'm not a great coder but got the job done.

Fun project if you want to build it yourself or with your kids, used coding for the LED patterns, 3D printing design, wiring it all up, and patience! Cheers.
